document.masterDocTitle: The Stephanidae (Hymenoptera) of Mexico, with description of six new species and key to western Foenatopus Smith

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The Stephanidae (Hymenoptera) of Mexico, with description of six new species and key to western Foenatopus Smith

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology Named after the country of Mexico , as the most characteristic stephanid species of this region.

FEMALE. Holotype specimen ( Figs 24 , 87–91, 93, 95 ). Body length 10.5 mm . Head: Antenna with 30 flagellomeres, f1 ventrally dilated, laterally flattened; f2 ventrally on central 0.3 perceptibly swollen; f3–6 very long and narrow, about 15 times as long as wide; f7 basal 0.3 cylindric, apical 0.7 somewhat widened; f8–25 as wide as f7 apex; f26–30 progressively shorter and smaller. Flagellomeres 1–6 corresponding to 0.35 of the flagellar length; width widening of apical portion of flagellum distinct, clearly dividing antennae in two major sections. Frons rugose approximately in zig­zag, ventrally rugosity transverse, changing to dorsally oblique. Coronal tubercles well defined, hind tubercles mesal margin widely separated, ending at anterior margin of first interocellar carina. Vertex ( Fig. 87 ) glabrous; two interocellar carina, first one strong, darkened, shaped as a square bracket (“[”), second weak, more irregular; main area densely transversely rugose, changing progressively from strong anteriorly to fine posteriorly; rugosity reaching occipital carina centrally, becoming very weak laterally, disappearing on temple. Gena polished; in dorsal view very weakly prominent; centrally and ventrally with sparse long pale hairs. Occipital carina ( Fig. 87 ) narrow, sharp, translucent; in dorsal view deeply emarginate into vertex, semicircular; in posterior view weakly convergent ventrally, ending far from hypostomal carina, at a distance almost as long as length of scape.

Metasoma: Petiole basal end rugulose, with a few longitudinal wrinkles, changing to coarsely microfoveolate and then progressively to finely and delicately microareolate towards apex, including ventrally; dorso­apical margin polished; T3 (2 nd metasomal) finely but conspicuously longitudinally alutaceous; T4 very finely transversely strigulatealutaceous; T5–7 transversely microscopically strigulate; T8 coarsely alutaceous. In full lateral view, metasoma with fine matte texture due to its generalized fine and dense sculpture pattern.

Morphological variation in females. Range of biometric values in Table 1. All specimens very similar, but mesonotal rugosity, including scutellum, can be considerably coarser and more irregular than observed in the holotype , the median sulcus practically disappearing in this case.

Megischus mexicanus

sp. n.
, ♀. 87, head, dorsal, holotype; 88, pronotum + prosternum, left, holotype; 89, pronotum, dorsal; 90, propodeum + metapleuron, dorso­lateral left and slanted forward, holotype; 91, hind left tibia, posterior view, holotype; 92, mesonotum, including scutellum, also part of crenulate sulcus, paratype OSUC22877; 93, crenulate sulcus, interfoveolar area, propodeum + metapleuron, left, holotype; 94, hind left coxa, mesal, paratype OSUC22878; 95, ovipositor and sheaths, lateral, holotype. Illustrations not to scale.
